Do you think they didn't give -- do you think it didn't give the Commission power without regard to name if the barges were being charged -- if you were charging more for the transportation of stuff that came over a barge as to the stuff that came over a railroad that Congress is -- the ICC is without power to prevent the discrimination.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Sir, I just pointed out that the ICC does have the power under Section 611 (b) to establish proportional rates of whatever amount they desire --
Well, they could --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: -- on X water trip.
Well, they could prevent this then, could they?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Why certainly, they could prevent it if they had raised the issue properly which they did not.
Now --
That -- that's your ground then, if they didn't start the proper proceedings and they haven't proceeded in the right way, now, that may be a good objection.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: What their case might be under six -- Section 611 (b), I don't know.
But counsel was offered that from the Commission.
I don't say offered it, they simply suggested it to him and he said no.
That would cure the discrimination.
They admit that, but that isn't what they want.
Do you mean, decreased rates?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Yes, sir.
I mean, or increase yours?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No change in ours.
(Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: They would simply decrease it as it applies to these people.
That's right.One more thing, there has been some testimony of pro and con about the absence or a non-absence of a showing of what service changes are here or differences.
There is no showing at all in this record, whether the services are the same or different, but let me point out just one thing to you as a matter of common sense.
When we receive all-rail traffic from our southwestern connections at East St.Louis, that sulphur is in cars, which is supplied by the Southwestern lines.
In maintaining our local rate between East St.Louis and Danville, it is we who must round up and supply all these empty cars.
In other words, on through all-rail traffic, our only duty would be to put a locomotive on the end of their train and take it away.
But here, just as a matter of common sense, we have to supply the cars from the traffic.
We have to round up these empties, put them down at the dock, how many of them we don't know because this comes up in 1,000-ton lots, but that's a considerable number of empties to supply.
So, there is at least that difference in the service.
Mr. Belnap, you have a few minutes.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Chief Justice, if the Court please, just on the last point as to supply of cars, these lines, of course, do not serve the barge terminals.
There's a switching line service for barge terminals.

The record is that federal barge lines and American barge lines, which are the terminating barge lines of East St.Louis, for cars supplied, pay per diem, the usual per diem rate for the cars throughout the terminal and pay a per diem reclaim the switching line.
Would you explain your viewpoint of what was said about the contract carrier --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Yes, sir.
-- and your -- and the contract barges in your argument?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: During the course of the oral argument in 1953, November, Mr. Daily argued the case for the railroads.
He talked about and I quote, “The traffic which we now have with the Missouri Pacific.”
That's on the record 139.
He spoke about a prior movement from Galveston by a contract carrier.
The evidence shows that in the latter part of 1950, there was such a movement by a contract carrier.

In the report of the Commission, upon reconsideration on page 30 of the record, decided in January 1954, this is said, “Beginning with and since 1951, the entire movement of sulphur from the Galveston area approximating 20,000 tons a year has been over at the all-rail routes.”
Is there anything to dispute that anywhere else in the record?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: No, sir.
So, that the result of all -- for some -- for some reason, all the sulphur now goes over the railroad.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: It all goes over the railroad.
I think in the examiner's proposed report, there was a statement that the contract carrier had gone out of business.
And in that --
On page 20 -- 24 of the Commission to the fifth division -- I mean the Division 3.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yes, but I'm going to --
(Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I -- may I say this to warn the Court about the misprint in this record.
Folio 33 on pages 22 to 24 has been interchanged with folio 25, which is on pages -- of the record, 11 and 12.
One is page 2 of the examiner's proposed report and the other is page 2 of the report of Division 3.
So, the matter to which Mr. Justice Frankfurter directed my attention --
The first full paragraph.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The first full paragraph, it's from page 20 --
Four, under the --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That is from the examiner's proposed report.
Oh, that's not from the report?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's not from the report of divisions.
And where does that (Inaudible)

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It should be in the place of folio 25, Mr. Justice, on pages 11 and 12 of the record.
Those two folios are interchanged in the print.
In the print.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: (Inaudible)
33 is the folio that's interchanged, Mr. Justice.
33 should be on --
Was that folio 34?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Well, if I did, I must spoke to myself.
Folio 33 on pages 22 to 24 of the print should be interchanged with folio 25, which is on pages 11 and 12 of the print.
In other words, folio 33 is folio 25.
That's what you mean.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Yes, it should be that way.
What page is 25 on?
Beginning at -- no, it's folio 33.
That's all right.
At page 25 is where it belongs.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: 25 is where it belongs.
The bottom half of page 24 is where it belongs.
The Commission --
Then that statement about the contract carrier, it was from the examiner's report?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That was from the examiner's report and not from the report of Division 3.
Anyhow, the facts are the same.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I have no doubt they are.
My time has expired.
You may -- you may answer the -- that last question.
Did you have a question?
Did you finish the -- did you finish your question?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, I didn't --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice

text_blocks.text: Thank you, sir.
I think it's all right.
All right.
Well --

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

transcript.title: Dixie Carriers, Inc. v. United States
